subject: Art
title: Shape Language
description: Circles feel friendly. Squares feel stable. Triangles feel dangerous. Shapes communicate.

hook.text: A villain built from sharp triangles. A hero built from strong squares. A sidekick built from soft circles. Shape language is a visual shorthand that communicates personality before the viewer reads a single word.

buildup.text: The big three: Circles = friendly, approachable, soft, youthful (think Baymax). Squares = strong, reliable, stable, tough (think Wreck-It Ralph). Triangles = dynamic, dangerous, cunning, fast (think Maleficent).

discovery.text: Shape language works because of psychological associations: round things in nature are usually safe (fruits, babies' faces). Sharp things are dangerous (thorns, fangs, cliffs). Our brains read shapes as signals BEFORE we read them as drawings.

twist.text: Subverting shape language creates interesting characters: a villain made of circles feels unsettlingly friendly (like Lots-o'-Huggin' Bear). A hero made of sharp angles feels dangerous but good (like Batman). Subversion adds complexity.

climax.text: Design the same character three times: once based on circles (friendly version), once based on squares (tough version), once based on triangles (threatening version). Same character concept, completely different personalities â€” just from shapes.

punchline.text: Shapes speak a language everyone understands. Choose your shapes and the personality follows.

quiz.question: What personality does triangle-based shape language typically communicate?
